body: Works normally after removing non-Latin-1 characters configured in $PATH

issue.title: [8.3.0] bazel crashed due to an internal error-Expected internal string with Latin-1 coder

milestone.title: 8.3.0 release blockers
milestone.description: Issues that should be fixed before 8.3.0 release.

repository.name: bazel
repository.description: a fast, scalable, multi-language and extensible build system

body:
I think that https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/blob/498a0c8e5547dea97f3049d8e1ea16fe9db4977d/src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/shell/WindowsSubprocessFactory.java#L143 is the real underlying bug. While `System.getenv` doesn't return a string in the correct internal encoding, it's wrong in an even worse way: the client emv may change while the server is running, resulting in an outdated view of the environment.

@tjgq Do you agree? In that case my fix would be to use the client env here. In fact, is it possible that `JavaSubprocessFactory` is also prone to this issue as it doesn't set `ProcessBuilder#environment()` to the client env?
I agree, using `System.getenv()` instead of the client env looks like a bug.

issue.title: Use the `clientEnv` instead of `System.getenv()` for `env`-less `SubprocessBuilder`

repository.name: bazel
repository.description: a fast, scalable, multi-language and extensible build system

issue.body:
This fixes a correctness issue as env variables can change between invocation against the same server.

Motivated by #26057

issue.title: Reencode strings obtained from `System.getenv`

body:
A fix for this issue has been included in[Bazel 8.3.0 RC1](https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/releases/tag/8.3.0rc1). Please test out the release candidate and report any issues as soon as possible.
If you're using Bazelisk, you can point to the latest RC by setting USE_BAZEL_VERSION=8.3.0rc1. Thanks!
